root.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
root.pub-comments: Special thanks to Dr. Anthony Diller (Australian National University) for his patience and helpfulness in addressing questions that arose while during the digitization of this tree. Refer to the Section 1.4 of Diller 2008 for a discussion of the various terms that have been proposed in the naming of this language family, including 'Tai', 'Thai', 'Kadai'.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: According to Diller (personal correspondence), 'Zhuang-Dong' is the name used officially by both scholars and authorities in mainland China.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: According to Diller (personal correspondence), 'Zhuang-Tai' (or 'Zhuang-Dai') is the name used officially by both scholars and authorities in mainland China.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: Diller 2008 actually named this node '(Southwestern)'; the parentheses indicate uncertainty about this branching (personal correspondence). Diller (personal correspondence) further stipulates that the languages in this subgroup can be further grouped as follows: {Lue, Thai, So. Thai, Lana, Lao}, {Black Tai, White Tai, Red Tai, Phu Tai}, and {Shan, Dehong, Khamti, Phake, Aiton, Ahom}.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: Though this node does not exist in the source, Diller (personal correspondence) seems to feel strongly about Black Tai, White Tai, Red Tai, and Phu Tai being grouped together under Southwestern Tai.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: According to Diller (personal correspondence), this language, unlike Black Tai and White Tai, is not officially recognized by the Vietnamese government, "[s]o Vietnamese authorities and scholars who follow their [the government's] views consider Red Tai as either a kind of White or Black." Diller himself would consider Red Tai a separate language, though he acknowledges that there is disagreement, even among native speakers.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.alt-names: Tai Dam, Tai Noir, Lao Song Dam, Lao Song
child.pub-comments: Diller 2008 observes that the names 'Lao Song Dam' and 'Lao Song' are used in Thailand for this language

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: Though this node does not exist in the source, Diller (personal correspondence) seems to feel strongly about Shan, Dehong, Khamti, Phake, Aiton, Ahom being grouped together under Southwestern Tai.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: This language is listed as extinct because is no longer spoken naturally, though it continues to be used in for religious purposes (Diller, personal correspondence); Diller 2008's tree originally listed this language between parentheses, as '(Ahom)'.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: According to Diller, 'Dai' in Chinese usage combines both speakers of Lue and Dehong, though linguistic practice reserves this term only for Lue.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: Though this node does not exist in the source, Diller (personal correspondence) seems to feel strongly about Lue, Thai, So. Thai, Lana, and Lao being grouped together under Southwestern Tai.

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5

Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: According to Diller 2008, 'Dai' in Chinese usage combines both speakers of Lue and Dehong, though linguistic practice reserves this term only for Lue; furthermore, 'Dai' is the name used officially by both scholars and authorities in mainland China (pesonal correspondence).

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: Diller 2008 actually named this node '(Central)'; the parentheses indicate uncertainty about this branching (personal correspondence).

child.pub-comments: Diller 2008 observes that the name 'Tho' "is now understood to be objectionable."

child.publications: Diller, Anthony V. N. 2008. Introduction. In Anthony V. N. Diller, Jerold A. Edmondson & Yongxian Luo (eds.), The Tai-Kadai Languages, 3–8. London: Routledge. ISBN 978-0-7007-1457-5
child.pub-comments: Diller 2008 actually named this node '(Northern)'; the parentheses indicate uncertainty about this branching (personal correspondence).
